items.title: US says 11 people killed in latest strikes on alleged drug boats
items.standfirst: Three boats targeted in eastern Pacific and Caribbean as Trump continues pursuit of alleged ‘narco-terrorists’US military officials have said American forces launched assaults on three alleged drug-smuggling boats, killing 11 in one of the deadliest days of the Trump administration’s months-long campaign against alleged traffickers.The military action on Monday brought the number of fatalities caused by US strikes to 145 since September, when Donald Trump called on American armed forces to attack people deemed “narco-terrorists” on small vessels. There have been 42 known strikes in notorious drug-trafficking routes such as the Caribbean Sea and eastern Pacific Ocean, according to the Associated Press reported. Continue reading...

James Talarico,” the network said in a statement.This is yet another troubling example of corporate capitulation in the face of this administration’s broader campaign to censor and control speech.The FCC has no lawful authority to pressure broadcasters for political purposes or to create a climate that chills free expression. Continue reading...

items.title: Russian and Belarusian athletes to compete under own flags at Paralympics
items.standfirst: Six Russians and four Belarusians will be allowed to take part under their own flags at the Milan-Cortina Paralympics rather than as neutral athletes, the Games' governing body has confirmed. Both countries were banned from Paralympic competitions after ​Moscow's 2022 invasion ‌of Ukraine, but regained full membership rights in the IPC after member ⁠organisations voted in September 2025 to lift their partial suspensions.
items.content: Six Russians and four Belarusians will be allowed to take part under their own flags at the Milan-Cortina Paralympics rather than as neutral athletes, the Games' governing body has confirmed. Both countries were banned from Paralympic competitions after ​Moscow's 2022 invasion ‌of Ukraine, but regained full membership rights in the IPC after member ⁠organisations voted in September 2025 to lift their partial suspensions.

clusters.title: ECB's Lagarde reportedly to leave before end of her term
clusters.neutral_headline: ECB President Lagarde to Leave Before Term End

items.title: ECB's Lagarde reportedly to leave before end of her term
items.standfirst: Christine Lagarde, the president of the European Central Bank, has decided to leave her position as the EU's top central banker before the end of her mandate in October 2027, according to a report in the Financial Times. The move could allow for her successor to be named ahead of presidential elections in France. Also in this edition, Venezuela's interim government issues its first statement on the disputed oil-rich territory of Essequibo.
items.content: Christine Lagarde, the president of the European Central Bank, has decided to leave her position as the EU's top central banker before the end of her mandate in October 2027, according to a report in the Financial Times. The move could allow for her successor to be named ahead of presidential elections in France. Also in this edition, Venezuela's interim government issues its first statement on the disputed oil-rich territory of Essequibo.

items.title: Lagarde Reported to Leave ECB Before Term End, UK CPI Falls | The Opening Trade 2/18/2026
items.standfirst: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde is expected to step down from her role before her eight-year term ends in October 2027, the Financial Times reported. Lagarde wants to leave before the French presidential election in April next year, which would allow French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Friedrich Merz to find her replacement together, the report said, citing an unidentified person familiar with her thoughts on the matter. It isn’t clear yet when she may exit. UK inflation dropped to its lowest level since March 2025, bolstering the case for an interest rate cut when the Bank of England meets next month. Consumer prices rose 3% in January from a year earlier, down from 3.4% the previous month when volatile components temporarily boosted inflation, the Office for National Statistics said Wednesday. It was in line with economists’ expectations, and slightly above the 2.9% forecast by the BOE. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde is expected to step down from her role before her eight-year term ends in October 2027, the Financial Times reported. Lagarde wants to leave before the French presidential election in April next year, which would allow French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Friedrich Merz to find her replacement together, the report said, citing an unidentified person familiar with her thoughts on the matter. It isn’t clear yet when she may exit. UK inflation dropped to its lowest level since March 2025, bolstering the case for an interest rate cut when the Bank of England meets next month. Consumer prices rose 3% in January from a year earlier, down from 3.4% the previous month when volatile components temporarily boosted inflation, the Office for National Statistics said Wednesday. It was in line with economists’ expectations, and slightly above the 2.9% forecast by the BOE. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: Lagarde to leave ECB before end of 8-year term
items.standfirst: Central banker wants to give Macron and Merz chance to pick successor before French presidential election
items.content: Central banker wants to give Macron and Merz chance to pick successor before French presidential election

The move may impact the bank's monetary policy and direction

items.title: More than 80 UN member states condemn Israel’s plans to expand in West Bank
items.standfirst: UN missions from 85 member states on Tuesday condemned what they described as Israel’s expanding control in the West Bank, warning it could amount to de facto annexation. In a joint statement, they said unilateral measures violated international law and urged Israel to reverse them immediately.
items.content: UN missions from 85 member states on Tuesday condemned what they described as Israel’s expanding control in the West Bank, warning it could amount to de facto annexation. In a joint statement, they said unilateral measures violated international law and urged Israel to reverse them immediately.

items.title: Israel approves West Bank land registration amid Palestinian condemnation
items.standfirst: Israel's cabinet approved further measures to tighten Israel's control over the occupied West Bank and make it easier for settlers to buy land, a move Palestinians condemn. NBC News' Matt Bradley reports from Tel Aviv on how this might impact a two-state solution.
items.content: Israel's cabinet approved further measures to tighten Israel's control over the occupied West Bank and make it easier for settlers to buy land, a move Palestinians condemn. NBC News' Matt Bradley reports from Tel Aviv on how this might impact a two-state solution.

clusters.title: France arrests two more suspects over fatal beating of far-right activist in Lyon
clusters.neutral_headline: French Authorities Arrest Suspects Over Far Right Activist Killing

items.title: France arrests two more suspects over fatal beating of far-right activist in Lyon
items.standfirst: French authorities on Wednesday arrested two more suspects over the fatal beating of 23-year-old far-right activist Quentin Deranque on the sidelines of a protest in Lyon last week, bringing the total number of those detained to 11. The killing has heightened political tensions ahead of municipal elections next month.
items.content: French authorities on Wednesday arrested two more suspects over the fatal beating of 23-year-old far-right activist Quentin Deranque on the sidelines of a protest in Lyon last week, bringing the total number of those detained to 11. The killing has heightened political tensions ahead of municipal elections next month.

items.title: MP's assistant among 9 arrested over French far-right activist's killing
items.standfirst: French authorities on Tuesday arrested nine suspects over the killing last week of far-right activist Quentin Deranque, who died after he was attacked on the sidelines of a protest against a left-wing politician speaking at a university in the southeastern city of Lyon. Among those arrested was assistant to Raphael Arnault, a member of parliament from the hard-left France Unbowed (LFI) party.
items.content: French authorities on Tuesday arrested nine suspects over the killing last week of far-right activist Quentin Deranque, who died after he was attacked on the sidelines of a protest against a left-wing politician speaking at a university in the southeastern city of Lyon. Among those arrested was assistant to Raphael Arnault, a member of parliament from the hard-left France Unbowed (LFI) party.

items.title: Eleven arrested over killing of far-right activist Quentin Deranque in France
items.standfirst: Assistant to hard-left parliamentarian among those held over fatal attack on 23-year-old during protest in LyonFrench authorities have arrested 11 suspects over the killing last week of a far-right activist, including an assistant to a hard-left member of parliament, a prosecutor and an informed source said.Quentin Deranque, 23, died after sustaining a severe brain injury when he was attacked by at least six people on the sidelines of a far-right protest against a leftwing politician speaking at a university in the south-eastern city of Lyon. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: In a first, shark seen on camera in Antarctica waters, surprising researchers

clusters.title: Trump administration is erasing history and science at national parks, lawsuit argues
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Administration Sued Over National Park Policies

items.title: Trump administration is erasing history and science at national parks, lawsuit argues
items.standfirst: Conservation and historical organizations sued the Trump administration on Tuesday over National Park Service policies that the groups say erase history and science from America's national parks.
items.content: Conservation and historical organizations sued the Trump administration on Tuesday over National Park Service policies that the groups say erase history and science from America's national parks.(Image credit: Matt Rourke)

items.title: Trump officials sued over effort to ‘erase history and science’ in national parks
items.standfirst: National Park Service also sued for removing rainbow Pride flag from Stonewall national monument in New YorkConservation and historical organizations sued the Trump administration on Tuesday over National Park Service policies that the groups say erase history and science from America’s national parks.A lawsuit filed in Boston says orders by Donald Trump and interior secretary Doug Burgum have forced park service staff to remove or censor exhibits that share factually accurate and relevant US history and scientific knowledge, including about slavery and climate change. Continue reading...
items.content: National Park Service also sued for removing rainbow Pride flag from Stonewall national monument in New YorkConservation and historical organizations sued the Trump administration on Tuesday over National Park Service policies that the groups say erase history and science from America’s national parks.A lawsuit filed in Boston says orders by Donald Trump and interior secretary Doug Burgum have forced park service staff to remove or censor exhibits that share factually accurate and relevant US history and scientific knowledge, including about slavery and climate change. Continue reading...

The lawsuit claims that the policies violate the law and harm the national parks
The incident highlights concerns over the administration's environmental and historical policies

clusters.title: Dozens of filmmakers slam Berlin Film Festival's ‘silence’ on Gaza

items.title: Dozens of filmmakers slam Berlin Film Festival's ‘silence’ on Gaza
items.standfirst: More than 80 film industry figures, including Oscar winners Javier Bardem and Tilda Swinton, accused the Berlin Film Festival of “institutional silence” on Gaza in a statement on Tuesday. The open letter said signatories were appalled, while jury president Wim Wenders, when asked, said the festival could not “enter politics”.
items.content: More than 80 film industry figures, including Oscar winners Javier Bardem and Tilda Swinton, accused the Berlin Film Festival of “institutional silence” on Gaza in a statement on Tuesday. The open letter said signatories were appalled, while jury president Wim Wenders, when asked, said the festival could not “enter politics”.

items.title: Javier Bardem and Tilda Swinton among those to condemn Berlinale’s ‘silence’ on Gaza
items.standfirst: At least 80 film-makers and stars sign open letter after German festival jury president Wim Wenders says they should keep out of politicsMore than 80 current and former participants of the Berlinale, including Javier Bardem, Tilda Swinton and Adam McKay have signed an open letter condemning the festival’s “silence” on Gaza.It comes after the film festival was swept up in what it called a “media storm” over the alleged sidelining of political discourse at the event. Continue reading...

Continue reading...
